target_title: Dia 0.98 (from Git sources) lacks "pango-eps" export filter for EPS export

note.body:
The postscript/pango plugin was removed in d2ccbfb0344d3c23719fcb9661e2623830a0142d and 8d03d8a653c33d287ec960a3313cb1303e952df5; the cairo-based implementation was added in c1bb63de12d84e0fc605898d363c95dc5d858e8e.

So instead of `eps-pango`, you want to use `cairo-eps` now.

target_title: Dia 0.98 (from Git sources) lacks "pango-eps" export filter for EPS export

note.body: If Ubuntu screws up dependencies that's an Ubuntu issue, not a GNOME issue?

target_title: Dia 0.98 (from Git sources) lacks "pango-eps" export filter for EPS export

note.body:
The pango-eps filter is also missing when building Dia from the Git sources:
~/src/dia/build/install$ LD_LIBRARY_PATH=lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH bin/dia --list-filters | grep pango

target_title: Dia 0.98 (from Git sources) lacks "pango-eps" export filter for EPS export
GCC Strict Step 000:(#37 partial fix) - removed warnings for current build settings; no extra warnings added

note.body:
The reason for this is that there are three enums in  lib/font.h that are combined, in a non-overlapping way, into a single variable.
````
DiaFontFamily
DiaFontSlant
DiaFontWeight
````
There are even macros, that will bit mask and bit shift a single, unaligned value into the correct enum. E.g.:
````
#define DIA_FONT_STYLE_GET_FAMILY(st)    ((st) & (0x3))
#define DIA_FONT_STYLE_GET_SLANT(st)     ((st) & (0x3<<2))
#define DIA_FONT_STYLE_GET_WEIGHT(st)    ((st) & (0x7<<4))
````

The broader fix to this would be to deprecate the three enums, in favor of a replacement combined enum.

I'll make the proposed change for your purview as a separate MR.

An alternative approach would be to separate the single variable in the objects and structures into three separate variables, used and tested independently.  For now I'll proceed with the former approach.

target_title: Fix Gtk3 deprecations

note.body:
The point is to avoid exploding the build with endless warnings all at once

Of course this will mean that some changes will end up effectively ‘pointless’ by the time we reach gtk4, but it also means we can have greater confidence we didn't mess something up

At some point (we can push it to the end of the process); I will need someone to champion the msys2/mingw32 build issues.

note.body: The GCC warnings can be turned on one at a time, … In stead of going full `warning_level=2`, which will break the pipelines for mixed batches, what do you think if I progress by one GCC warning per merge request?

note.body: 100% ACK. But for people really working with día - creating and modifying diagrams - it is super important the application reacts fast ans is not this laggy. Removing the preview brings back the old behavior. Issue #552 is really a terrible thing.

My guess is that a distribution packaged Dia with a patch to replace the font selector with GtkFontButton. If that's the case, maybe we could import the patch in this upstream repository.

target_title: Text preferences window needs long time (3-4 seconds) to appear

note.body:
> Installing the package texlive-fonts-extra brings back this issue. When opening the text preferences window, dia 0.98 consumes a lot of CPU power. It becomes pretty unusable because of the long delays when texlive-fonts-extra is deployed.

Indeed, installing this package pulls *lot of* new fonts, which exacerbates the problem.
 
> Moreover, for reasons I cannot explain, removing texlive-fonts-extra does not speed things up again.

I don't understand neither. I see the same behaviour (on a Debian Sid system), even after `fc-cache -f -v` to regenerate the font cache and rebooting.


Anyway, I had a look and the problem seems to come from the rendering of each font item in the font it represents. If I remove the following line https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/dia/-/blob/adba518eceebb2c86f73275b66b6469b76480ad6/lib/dia-font-selector.c#L499, the loading of the window doesn't take several seconds anymore.
